# Understanding GitHub Actions

GitHub Actions is a robust platform for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) that enables you to automate various aspects of your software development process. It allows you to create workflows that automate tasks such as building, testing, and deploying your code. These workflows can be triggered by events like code pushes, pull requests, and more.

GitHub Actions provides virtual machines (VMs) with Linux, Windows, and macOS operating systems, which can be used to execute your workflow. Alternatively, you can set up your own self-hosted runners in your data center or cloud infrastructure for more control.

In essence, GitHub Actions acts as a kind of virtual environment, akin to a Virtual Private Server (VPS) or a Virtual Machine (VM), that can perform automated tasks. These tasks are configured using a workflow file written in YML format.

# Story

In the context of my GitHub projects, I stumbled upon GitHub Actions. After researching it in GitHub's documentation, I realized its potential for [streamlining deployment processes](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/deployment/about-deployments/deploying-with-github-actions) in my projects. This newfound knowledge sparked the idea of leveraging GitHub Actions for bug bounty automation, and I decided to give it a shot.

# How to Implement GitHub Actions

Here's a simplified guide on how to get started with GitHub Actions:

1. Navigate to your GitHub repository.
2. Access the "Actions" section of your repository.
3. Set up a workflow by defining a YML file.
4. Enjoy the benefits of automated tasks in your software development process.

# Explaining the Workflow File

Here's an overview of the key elements in a sample GitHub Actions workflow file:

```yaml
name: learn-github-actions
on: [push]

jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: Checkout Repo
        uses: actions/checkout@master
      
      - name: Setup golang
        uses: actions/setup-go@v2
        with:
          go-version: '^1.14.14'
          
      - name: Setup go tools
        run: |
          go version
          go install -v github.com/projectdiscovery/subfinder/v2/cmd/subfinder@latest    
          
      - name: Run Subfinder
        run: subfinder -silent -dL scope.txt -o subfinder.txt
```

- `name: learn-github-actions` specifies the name of the workflow.
- `on: [push]` triggers the workflow whenever there's a code push event.
- `jobs:` groups the tasks that need to be executed.
- `runs-on: ubuntu-latest` configures the job to run on the latest version of Ubuntu Linux.
- `uses: actions/checkout@master` copies the repository files to the VM.
- `uses: actions/setup-go@v2` installs Go, a requirement for running `subfinder`.
- The `run` commands execute various steps in the workflow.
- [Workflow-Syntax](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions_)

# Limitations of GitHub Actions

GitHub Actions, while versatile, has certain limitations, including:

- **Job execution time**: Each job can run for up to 6 hours. If it exceeds this limit, it's terminated.
- **Workflow run time**: Each workflow run is limited to 35 days.
- **API requests**: Limited to 1,000 requests per hour across all actions in a repository.
- **Concurrent jobs**: The number of concurrent jobs depends on your GitHub plan.
- **Job matrix**: A job matrix can generate a maximum of 256 jobs per workflow run.
- **Workflow run queue**: A maximum of 500 workflow runs can be queued in a 10-second interval.
- Read about this in [GitHub-Actions-Limits](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/usage-limits-billing-and-administration)
# Tips and Workarounds

To make the most of GitHub Actions, consider the following:

- Avoid running resource-intensive tasks.
- Use small bash scripts for running multiple commands.
- Employ webhooks for notifications, such as sending results through messaging services like Telegram Bots .
`cat results.txt | curl -X POST -F "document=@-" "https://api.telegram.org/bot<YOUR-BOT-TOKEN>/sendDocument" -F "chat_id=<YOUR-CHAT-ID>"`

For setting up notifications via Telegram:

1. Create a Telegram bot through @BotFather.
2. Note the HTTP API Token provided.
3. Use this token and the chat ID to send results to your Telegram bot.

![bot-notification](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

# Benefits of GitHub Actions

GitHub Actions offers several advantages:

- Easy setup and configuration.
- No need for extensive logging.
- No additional cost.
- Data availability for easy access and reference.
- Automation possibilities are vast and can simplify various tasks.

# Conclusion

GitHub Actions, when used within its limits, is a powerful tool for automating tasks like reconnaissance. I've personally set up a private workflow to handle my reconnaissance tasks and deliver results via a Telegram bot. This opens up possibilities for hands-free automation, allowing you to focus on other activities while GitHub Actions takes care of repetitive tasks. The potential applications are endless, and I encourage you to explore and experiment with this tool to see how it can enhance your development and automation workflows. If you come up with innovative uses, feel free to share them!
